w:r.w:t: The teacher will teach colors and shapes by using TPR, sentence frames, and vocabulary. Students will study these words and phrases: circle, triangle, square, rectangle, pentagon, hexagon, big, bigger, sides, I see a ____, It has _____ sides,
At completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce the words for shapes and colors
Spell and pronounce common associated words
Use sets of words in complete sentences
Word List: circle, triangle, square, rectangle, pentagon, hexagon,
This slide will always be the
-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: “Today, we are going to be learning about shapes.
and “draw” a circle with your fingers
Trace the circle with the drawing tool on the screen
Chant the poem to the child to the tune of “Hi-ho the Derry O,” while “drawing” circles with your finger. Encourage child to draw a circle with their fingers as well.
Trace the circle on the screen. Clear the screen and have the child do the same. Say,
and have the student do the same.
Visual cue: Show a ball each time you say, “A circle’s like a ball”
I see a square, I see a rectangle
Point to your eyes and say, “I see a square,” and “I see a rectangle.”
and have the child do the same.
Visual cue: Show some small real objects that are square and rectangular in shape
I see a triangle, I see a trapezoid
Point to your eyes and say, “I see a triangle,” and “I see a trapezoid.”
and have the child do the same
Visual cue: Show some small real objects or pictures that are triangle and trapezoid shaped
I see a pentagon, I see a hexagon
Point to your eyes and say, “I see a pentagon,” and “I see a hexagon.”
and have the child do the same
Visual cue: Show some small real objects/pictures that are a pentagon or hexagon shape
Review and say the name of the shapes
Circle the shape your teacher names
Review and say the name of the shapes, have the child repeat
Say a random shape and have your child circle the correct shape
Practice until the child has learned most of the shapes without help
Draw a line on the screen to match up the shape with the name of the shape
Say the name of each shape and read the shape words
Encourage student to draw a line to match the shapes with their shape name. Do the first one if necessary.
Circle a shape in random order and have the student say the name of the shape. Then have the student read the shape names by underlining one shape wo
Trace the sides using the drawing tool on the screen
when your teacher asks, “How many sides does it have?”
and do an action (put hand sideways and show it four times to make a square). Have child do the same.
Trace the sides of the shape on the screen. Clear the screen and encourage the student to do the same.
Ask the student, “How many sides do you see?” M
to help prompt the child to tell how many sides are on the shape in the picture. The child should answer, “It has four sides.”
Circle one shape at random and ask, “How many sides does it have?” Model tracing the sides of the shape you circled to prompt the student. The student should answer in a
complete sentence, “It has ______ sides.” Correct the student if necessary.
has three sides, It has six sides”

Circle one shape at random and ask, “How many sides does it have?” Model tracing the sides of the shape you circled to prompt the student. The student should answer in a complete sentence, “It has ______ sides.” Correct the student if necessary.
It is orange, it is brown, it is yellow, it is green
Circle the color your teacher names
Use color words in a complete sentence
The students should know most of their color names from Track 1. Review these color names.
Name a color and have the child circle it. Gesture with your finger. Use the color word in a complete sentence, “It is orange.”
It is blue, it is pink, it is red it is purple
Circle the color your teacher names
Use color words in a complete sentenc
The students should know most of their color names from Track 1. Review these color names.
Name a color and have the child circle it. Gesture with your finger. Use the color word in a complete sentence, “It is blue.”
Find and tell what colors objects in the picture are
: brown, yellow, pink, red, green, purple, orange
Ask the student, “What color are the flowers?” and circle the flower. The child should answer with the correct color name. Repeat with different objects in the pictures.
Visual cue: Review color names by showing real objects of different colors. Have the
child say what color they see.
The teacher should ask, “What color is the square?” The student should answer with the correct color name and in a complete sentence. Repeat with all the shapes.
The teacher should ask, “What color is the pentagon?” The student should answer with the correct color name and in a complete sentence. Repeat with all the shapes.
Student should circle the larger animal in each picture
by circling the big animal and the bigger animal in each pair. Then do an action for
spread them apart more for bigger). Have child do the action as well.

Ask, “What shape is bigger?” Encourage and really guide the child to answer in a complete sentence, “The pentagon is bigger.”

lete sentence, “The purple shape is bigger.”

Ask, “What shape is bigger?” Encourage and really guide the child to answer in a complete sentence, “The square is bigger.”

Identify most of the shapes of the dog and the colors of the shapes
Tell complete sentences about the color and shapes seen on the dog
Circle a part of the dog. Ask what color and shape it is. Encourage and model for the child to answer in complete sentences
